content:
She is the first female rap artist to enter the rap-span">Songwriters Hall of Fame

THE SURPRISING thing about the rap-span">induction of rap-span">Missy rap-span">Elliott into the rap-span">Songwriters Hall of Fame this year is not that it has taken too long—the usual complaint of fans—but that it has happened so soon. A writer becomes rap-span">eligible for membership 20 years after their first commercial release. Ms rap-span">Elliott’s solo career began in 1997 so it has taken little more than two years of rap-span">eligibility for her to receive the honour. It is richly deserved, given the rap-span">consistently high quality of her music, but it is surprising nonetheless, given that the institution rarely recognises hip-hop artists. Ms rap-span">Elliott is only rap’s third rap-span">inductee after rap-span">Jay-Z and rap-span">Jermaine Dupri, and its first such woman.

Ms rap-span">Elliott is one of the true rap-span">geniuses of the form. She is to rap what Prince was to R’n’B, both in terms of her impact upon the rap-span">genre and her ability to weave in styles and strands from outside it. Her first major hit, “Sock It 2 Me”—a rap-span">jaunty rap-span">paean to the joys of heterosexual sex, a subject she has always celebrated with candour—sampled the Delfonics’ “Ready or Not Here I Come (Can’t Hide from Love)”, which had only the previous year been the rap-span">basis of a hit for the Fugees. Where their version amounted to rap rap-span">karaoke, Ms rap-span">Elliott used its horn hook to build a rap-span">catchy new tune, creating something rap-span">altogether fresh.

She would do the same in following years with other then-rap-span">fashionable sounds. “Miss E… So rap-span">Addictive” (2001) reworked rap-span">garage, house and bhangra; “Under Construction” (2002) channelled “Dirty South” hip-hop, with its rap-span">emphasis on its soul and rap-span">funk roots; “This Is Not A Test!” (2003) nodded to crunk. She has always taken sources from the present and made them feel as if they come from the future, by rap-span">dint of rap-span">deploying them in ways nobody else has yet thought of. Her wild, rap-span">lewd humour and her rap-span">knack (building on black vernacular) for making language into a form of rap-span">percussion (“You think you can handle this badonkadonk-donk?”) are key to her method, as is her capacity to switch between an rap-span">inimitable rap style and sweet, rap-span">melodic vocals. These qualities have made her music instantly recognisable even as it has rap-span">evolved. 

There are only six rap-span">Missy rap-span">Elliott albums, running from “Supa Dupa Fly” in 1997 to “The rap-span">Cookbook” in 2005—a long-promised seventh has yet to appear—yet there is no more rap-span">formidable body of work in hip-hop. Unlike Prince, she has relied on rap-span">collaborators to realise her vision. Timbaland, her writing and producing partner, and rap-span">Hype Williams, an outstanding video director, were both crucial to her early success. Perhaps a more apt rap-span">analogy would be that she was to the turn of the rap-span">millennium what Bob Dylan was to the 1960s and David rap-span">Bowie the 1970s: an artist who not only redefined her rap-span">medium but the rap-span">culture around it, too. In Ms rap-span">Elliott’s case, she became a rap-span">figurehead for a more playful style of rap that gave away nothing in force and in swagger.

So why is it that Ms rap-span">Elliott is not recognised as belonging in the same rank of solo artists as Prince, rap-span">Bowie and Mr Dylan, and that such a question might rap-span">elicit scorn? It is not as if she is an rap-span">obscure or rap-span">cult figure. Only one of her albums has failed to go rap-span">platinum in America; she has four rap-span">Grammy wins and 22 rap-span">nominations to her name. “Work It”, “Get Ur rap-span">Freak On” and “4 My People” are treasured hits. In 2015, as a guest artist with rap-span">Katy rap-span">Perry, she took part in the most watched rap-span">halftime performance in Super Bowl history.

The answer lies, at least in part, in the fact that she is female. While women are often celebrated as singers and stars, it is much more diffirap-span">cult for them to be recognised as game-changing creative forces (in recent years critics have rap-span">opined on “the sexism of ‘rap-span">genius’” ). Moreover, she is a woman in rap, a music form that is on the whole still rap-span">notoriously rap-span">macho and remains subject to the rap-span">hoariest of rap-span">cultural rap-span">prejudices regarding race. Ms rap-span">Elliott has faced this double battle with determination, matching her male rap-span">counterparts for rap-span">brazen rap-span">braggadocio, mixed with rap-span">gleefully rap-span">assertive sexuality, and underpinned by sheer talent and rap-span">ingenuity. She has been as vital to forging a path in rap for female artists as rap-span">Patti Smith and rap-span">Joni Mitchell were for rock performers and singer-songwriters respectively. Like Ms Smith and Ms Mitchell, her impact on music more widely has been rap-span">overlooked in favour of her influence on women—as if nobody else had picked up on her ideas.

Credit, then, to the rap-span">Songwriters Hall of Fame for its acknowledgement of Ms rap-span">Elliott’s rap-span">artistry. It will hardly be news to her numerous fans, but it will be rap-span">heartening if the rap-span">accolade rap-span">prompts a wider reevaluation of her standing.

eg2: Only now the Blue  was more important than ever because he alone had stayed the color blue and people argued about what that meant.

事实上，我建议你将关注的重点从自己转移到他们身上。他们是那么富有才华的演说家吗？他们的想法比你的想法更好吗？
